intro: Vincetoxicum parviurnulum, commonly known as the small-flowered greenbrier, is a climbing shrub native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the family Rubiaceae and is characterized by its trifoliate leaves and small, greenish-white flowers. The plant produces small, red berries that are toxic to humans and animals. It thrives in moist, wooded areas and is often found in the understory of forests. Its botanical features make it a notable but cautionary species in ecological studies.
